snippet.title: Purple Place - Classic Games - PC Gameplay (Steam)
snippet.description:
Do you remember Windows Vista? More specifically, remember when you played a little game called Purble Place when you were a kid at home or school?

Well, so do I. And while I was browsing Steam, I was shocked (and/or surprised) to learn that this saw a Steam release under the name "Purple Place - Classic Games" was getting a re-release, complete with achievement support. Once it came out, I HAD to buy it, as it was at a launch discount. But then I checked the game's Steam discussions

Turns out it was actually a clone of the original Purble Place made entirely in Unity. The original developer is stated as "Oberon Games" who were later acquired by "iWin, Inc." It's interesting seeing no mention of either of these companies; not to mention the original publisher being Microsoft itself.

It's a knockoff with all new art made to imitate the look of the original. Compare screenshots from this store page to the original and you'll see it's not the same. At least it sells for a fair price. And technically the game is completely legal since it doesn't use the same name and all the art assets are new. But it's just a clone. Functionally, the game is the same though so I'm sure it's good enough to fulfill the nostalgia people like myself have for the game. Though maybe they'll notice if the sound effects and music are significantly different. Then again, the original Purble Place was a game that came free with Windows Vista (and Windows 7 for that matter) as pre-installed titles. But starting with Windows 8, the game is no longer accessible through official means unless you go to a freeware website, so I suppose this clone is definitely a modern and harmless alternative. But who knows how long it will be up for sale before it gets delisted from Steam for whatever reason...

Purble Place is (presumably) owned by Microsoft and iWin, Inc.
Purple Place (the clone) is developed by Sam Cohle
